We follow the [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/) standard, with an extension for more specific types:

| Type       | When to use                                                        |
|------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `feat`     | New feature or endpoint                                            |
| `fix`      | Bug fixes                                                         |
| `refactor` | Internal refactoring without behavior change                      |
| `style`    | Changes that do not affect behavior (spaces, formatting)           |
| `docs`     | Documentation changes                                              |
| `test`     | Adding or modifying tests                                          |
| `build`    | Changes to the build process (Makefile, Dockerfile, etc)           |
| `ci`       | Changes to pipelines, GitHub Actions, etc                          |
| `chore`    | Dependency updates, configs, administrative tasks                  |
| `revert`   | Reverting a previous commit                                       |

### Example:

feat(api): add endpoint for user creation
fix(auth): fix JWT token expiration
refactor(service): move retry logic to middleware
chore(deps): update Go to 1.22
docs: update README with build instructions. ALL COMMITS MUST BE IN TECHNICAL ENGLISH, BRIEF BUT DO NOT OMIT ANY MODIFICATION.
